Britain’s most notorious prisoner Charles Bronson is reported to have proposed to a former Coronation Street actress. 
Paula Williamson, 36, was popped the question by jailbird Bronson, 64, when she visited him at HMP Wakefield. 
The actress appeared on the cobbles three times between 2008 and 2012 in bit parts as an unnamed nurse working at Weatherfield General. 
In one episode she is seen caring for Fiz Brown, played by Jennie McAlpine, when the character had recently given birth. 
Paula, who graduated from the school of theatre at Manchester Metropolitan University in 2005, has also appeared in Hollyoaks, Scott & Bailey and Emmerdale. Paula Williamson visits Charles Bronson at Wakefield Prison (Photo: Daily Mirror) Read More Dale Cregan feared 'ending up like Charles Bronson' in plot to move to psychiatric hospital 
She was pictured outside the prison in a revealing red dress ahead of the meeting. 
Bronson is said to have planned the proposal for Valentine’s Day, but brought it forward for her visit. 
He has spent 41 years in prison, initially for armed robbery and has had his sentence increased for attacking prison guards and taking them hostage. 
A biopic about his life starring Tom Hardy was released in 2008. 
The couple became friendly after becoming pen pals, and are thought to have been in a relationship for five months. 
Paula, from Stoke-on-Trent, said: “We are so in love. Wakefield Prison (Photo: Anders Hanson/ Flickr) Read More 
“I’ve had relationships with both men and women in the past, but none of them come close to my love for Charlie. 
“He’s so eccentric, but so am I. It’s a perfect match.” 
Paula said they will work to make their relationship work, despite Bronson being locked up. 
She added: “I know he has a public image of being a violent prisoner, but in reality he is so different. 
“He can never change the things he has done in the past, but he is working so hard to put that behind him. 
“There are obviously difficulties him being in prison cause our relationship, but we feel so strongly about each other we’re determined to make it work.” Like us on Facebook
